content.headline: Understanding and Supporting Maternal Mental Health
content.intro: The postpartum period brings significant emotional changes that affect mental health. Recognizing the spectrum of maternal mental health conditions—from common baby blues to more serious disorders—is essential for getting appropriate support and treatment. Your emotional wellbeing is just as important as your physical recovery.

sections.title: Spectrum of Postpartum Mental Health Conditions
sections.content: Understand the range of emotional experiences after childbirth:
points: Baby Blues: Temporary mood swings affecting 70-80% of new mothers
Postpartum Depression: Persistent sadness, anxiety lasting weeks or months
Postpartum Anxiety: Excessive worry, panic attacks, racing thoughts
Postpartum OCD: Intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors
Postpartum PTSD: Trauma response from difficult birth experience
Postpartum Psychosis: Rare but serious condition requiring immediate care

sections.title: Risk Factors and Prevention
sections.content: Certain factors may increase vulnerability to postpartum mental health challenges:
points: Personal or family history of depression or anxiety
Pregnancy or birth complications and trauma
Lack of social support or relationship stress
Financial pressures or housing instability
Sleep deprivation and physical exhaustion
Hormonal changes and genetic predisposition

sections.title: Support and Treatment Options
sections.content: Multiple approaches can help manage postpartum mental health:
points: Therapy and counseling for emotional processing and coping skills
Medication when recommended by healthcare providers
Support groups connecting with other experiencing mothers
Practical help with childcare, meals, and household tasks
Self-care practices like rest, nutrition, and gentle exercise
Partner and family education about supporting recovery

sections.title: When to Seek Professional Help
points: Symptoms lasting more than 2 weeks without improvement
Difficulty caring for yourself or your baby
Thoughts of harming yourself or your infant
Inability to sleep even when baby is sleeping
Withdrawing from family and friends completely
Feeling overwhelmed by anxiety or panic attacks
